title: {{< iconify twemoji flag-turkey >}} Turkish Local Elections 2024
text:
Methodology
In collaboration with Who Targets Me, we monitored 6686 political advertisers to better understand how campaigns use different targeting methods made available by Meta. To do this, we used data from the Meta Ad Library, using the new â€˜Audienceâ€™ data which gives some detail on how pages target their ads.






Note



Meta only provides 7, 30 and 90 days windows for the targeting data in their Ad Library. Metaâ€™s data also lags by a few days. Report will be updated as soon as new data is available.








Disclaimer



The data shown in this dashboard is based on the platformâ€™s respective ad libraries which are known to be sometimes incomplete (Edelson et al.Â 2020; Silva et al.Â 2020). For this reason the data shown here might not reflect the full picture nor all political ads that were targeted at voters.




About the Creators of the Dashboard

Onurcan GÃ¼denFabio Votta













Onurcan GÃ¼den is a PhD candidate in Media and Communication Studies at the Galatasaray University and a visiting researcher at the University of Amsterdam. His research focuses on the impact of computational propaganda in shaping digital political agendas in different democracies and its societal consequences.



















Fabio Votta is a Postdoc at the University of Amsterdam who studies (online) political microtargeting and its usage around the world.














Want to see how political parties target you? Sign up at Who Targets Me and download the gratis browser plugin to see how parties on Facebook use your data:
https://whotargets.me/







Want to retrieve targeting data from the Facebook Ad Library yourself? This dashboard is powered by the R package: metatargetr. Check it out here:
https://github.com/favstats/metatargetr




Election Targeting Dashboards

title: {{< iconify twemoji flag-turkey >}} Turkish Local Elections 2024
Analyzing the Landscape of Local Elections in TÃ¼rkiye: A Deep Dive into Micro-Targeted Advertising on Meta
text:
As we near the two-week countdown to the local elections in TÃ¼rkiye, the main opposition party, the CHP, has taken the lead in spending on micro-targeted ads across Meta platforms in the country. This represents a significant shift from last yearâ€™s presidential and parliamentary elections, during which the CHP lagged far behind the ruling AKP in Meta ad spend.
On the other hand, we observe that the AKP is channeling substantial funds into advertising in major cities such as Istanbul, Ä°zmir, Bursa, Antalya, Adana, Ordu, and Hatay. This demonstrates a strategic emphasis on the AKPâ€™s desire to take over municipalities it does not have. In contrast, the CHP outspends AKP in Ankara, Manisa, AydÄ±n, Denizli, and Malatya, indicating a nuanced approach to capturing different regional demographics.




In Istanbul, where 11,314,516 individuals are set to cast their votes, the AKP candidate, Murat Kurum (on the right), outspends his rival from the CHP, Ekrem Ä°mamoÄŸlu (on the left), by 3.2 times.



Elections become further complicated by the involvement of unofficial accounts, which play a pivotal role in shaping how voters perceive the candidates and issues. Pages like â€œÄ°stanbul GerÃ§ekleriâ€ specifically target Ekrem Ä°mamoÄŸlu, a prominent figure for the CHP in Ä°stanbul, with direct attack ads. Similarly, â€œAntalya GerÃ§ekleriâ€ in Antalya and â€œYeni Mikrofonâ€ in Ankara are actively engaged in negative campaigning against CHP candidates. On the flip side, â€œUnutma Ä°stanbulâ€ page seeks to sway voters by recalling the period when Istanbul was under AKP management.




The ad on the â€œÄ°stanbul GerÃ§ekleriâ€ page claims that Ekrem Ä°mamoÄŸlu has been using municipal funds for his own public relations purposes.



Examining the targeting dimensions of Meta ads reveals a strategy finely tuned to specific groups. The AKPâ€™s focus on parents with children in nursery and elementary schools, alongside the CHP is targeting users with a keen interest in Ottoman history, nationalist music, the â€œDiriliÅŸ ErtuÄŸrulâ€ series, and theology students and graduates.
As the local elections approach, the landscape of political advertising on Meta platforms provides a glimpse into the evolving tactics of voter persuasion in TÃ¼rkiye. The emergence of unofficial accounts and micro-targeted ads highlights the increasingly nuanced battle for hearts and minds in the digital arena.

title: Welcome to the 2024 Turkish Local Elections Dashboard
text:
Keep track on how political parties and other unlabelled actors use digital advertising on Meta and what audiences they are trying to reach.



Welcome to the 2024 Turkish Local Elections Dashboard. This dashboard is intended to provide an overview of how political parties and various actors are leveraging digital advertising on Meta platforms, targeting specific audiences. Our goal is to create transparency for citizens, journalists, and other interested parties, and helping you understand the strategies behind these digital campaigns as we approach the local elections.
Digital advertising is a powerful tool in modern political campaigns, and this dashboard opens up a window into common strategies. Whether youâ€™re interested in the tactics used by different parties or how theyâ€™re trying to reach potential voters, feel free to explore the data on this dashboard. Stay informed with us as we explore the role of digital advertising in the 2024 Turkish Local Elections.

title: Spending per Targeting
text:
Data for: All
These charts show the groups that political parties target with their advertisements leading up to the elections, according to the latest data. The focus is on Metaâ€™s platforms (Facebook and Instagram) because they offer the most detailed targeting options for political advertisements.
How much did the campaigns of political parties spend on different audiences? The charts below show both the total and the expenditures per party.

Note: Different targeting criteria may overlap, so the outcome may not necessarily add up to 100%.


15 Feb - 15 Mar 20249 Mar - 15 Mar 2024



TotalBy Party
